greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of acute integer triangles with perimeter n.
comment: An integer triangle [A070080(k) <= A070081(k) <= A070082(k)] is acute iff A070085(k) > 0.
link: Seiichi Manyama, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Acute Triangle.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=1..floor(n/3)} Sum_{i=k..floor((n-k)/2)} (1-sign(floor((n-i-k)^2/(i^2+k^2)))) * sign(floor((i+k)/(n-i-k+1))). - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, May 12 2019
example: For n=9 there are A005044(9)=3 integer triangles: [1,4,4], [2,3,4] and [3,3,3]; two of them are acute, as 2^2+3^2<16=4^2, therefore a(9)=2.
mathematica: Table[Sum[Sum[(1 - Sign[Floor[(n - i - k)^2/(i^2 + k^2)]]) Sign[Floor[(i + k)/(n - i - k + 1)]], {i, k, Floor[(n - k)/2]}], {k, Floor[n/3]}], {n, 100}] (* _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, May 12 2019 *)
results.author: _Reinhard Zumkeller_, May 05 2002
